title-group.article-title: Transient vibration and sound radiation of a stiffened plate

article-meta.aff: 1School of Architecture, Huaqiao University, Xiamen, People’s Republic of China
2Department of Building Services Engineering, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Cheuk Ming Mak, Department of Building Services Engineering, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong, People’s Republic of China Email: becmmak@polyu.edu.hk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The transient vibration and sound radiation (TVSR) of a stiffened plate was investigated using the time-domain finite element method and time-domain boundary element method. A four-noded stiffened-plate element was adopted in this method; this allowed the plate to have arbitrary elastic boundary conditions and the stiffeners with any shape to be located at arbitrary positions inside the plate. The in-plane deformation of the plate was taken into account. The transient vibration predicted by the present approach showed a good agreement with earlier published results. The proposed method was subsequently applied to a parametric study that examined the effects of the stiffeners on the TVSR of a window, which is a typical plate structure. The results showed that the stiffeners (or their locations) notably influenced the window’s TVSR responses, thereby demonstrating the possibility of using appropriate stiffeners to improve the transient vibration and noise isolation performance of a practical window.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Adding the stiffeners to a structure can influence structure dynamic characteristics (Langley, 1992; Yun and Mak, 2009). Plate-like structures are widely used as primary structural components (Yun and Mak, 2011; Zu and Mak, 2011), and hence a variety of models and theories have been developed to investigate the vibroacoustic response of plate structures with various types of stiffeners (Mace, 1980; Mead, 1990; Ginsberg and McDaniel, 1991; Lee and Kim, 2002; Joshi et al., 2010). The findings reveal that the parameters, such as the stiffener’s position and stiffness, can be utilized to improve the vibration isolation (or sound insulation) properties of the plate in the frequency range of interest. Another important factor that affects the vibroacoustic response is the plate’s boundary conditions (or boundary supports). With the development of approximate solution techniques, numerous studies (Berry et al., 1990; Chiello et al., 2003; Park et al., 2003; Ou and Mak, 2011b) have been conducted on this issue and demonstrate that the boundary conditions significantly affect the vibration and sound radiation performance of the plate especially in the low frequency domain.

Both the boundary conditions and the stiffeners have important effects and cannot be neglected in the analysis of the vibroacoustic response of a practical stiffened plate structure. Few available methods, however, can be found that can be used to predict the vibroacoustic response of stiffened plates by taking into account the effects of arbitrary boundary supports and arbitrarily located stiffeners at the same time. Berry and Locqueteau (1996) have proposed a Ritz model to calculate the vibroacoustic response of a stiffened plate that incorporated the effects of the stiffeners and the boundary transverse stiffness. However, the plate’s rotational boundary constraint that could have a significant effect on the vibroacoustic response was neglected in their model. Also, the stiffeners were limited to be parallel to the plate edges in their model.

As far as the vibroacoustic problems of stiffened plates is concerned, the time-harmonic excitation is a common assumption used in most existing models to simplify the problems to steady-state ones. However, a large number of the actual excitations in daily life are transient in nature (Akay, 1978). These excitations can include impact forces or impact sound waves—for example, the forces generated by working machines and human activities or the sound waves generated by industrial machines, military installations, construction work, pass-by aircrafts (sonic booms), and the take-off and landing of airplanes. The analysis of the time histories of the vibration and sound radiation of the structures to such excitations is important for the estimation of the important parameters such as the instantaneous displacement and acceleration, the instantaneous sound pressure and sound power, the peak (maximum) displacement and acceleration, and the peak (maximum) sound pressure.

The purpose of the current study is to develop a simple but effective method for estimating the transient vibration and sound radiation (TVSR) of the stiffened plate structure. This technique allows the computation of a plate with arbitrary elastic boundary conditions and with arbitrarily located stiffeners. The in-plane deformation of the plate is also taken into account which can improve the accuracy especially for the eccentrically stiffened plate (Berry and Locqueteau, 1996; Mukhopadhyay, 2011).The residential window is a typical plate structure, and it is natural for engineers to consider utilizing the boundary supports or stiffeners (or both) to improve the window’s vibration and noise isolation performance. The proposed approach can therefore be used to guide the design of a practical window with better TVSR insulation properties. The allowance of arbitrary elastic boundary conditions, stiffener shape and stiffener position makes the design more flexible. To meet these aims the time-domain finite element method (TDFEM) and time-domain boundary element method (TDBEM) were employed, in which a stiffened-plate element proposed by Barik and Mukhopadhyay (1999) was adopted. A summary of this numerical method is given in Section 2. Numerical results for the transient vibration of a stiffened plate are reported in Section 3 and compared with earlier published results. Parametric studies on an eccentrically stiffened window are also given to check the possibility of improving the TVSR insulation properties of a practical window by using stiffeners. Finally, Section 4 presents the conclusions.

sec.title: 2.1. Theoretical model
sec.p:
Consider a thin rectangular plate (e.g. a window) of length Lx, width Ly, thickness h stiffened by a stiffener (or stiffeners) at an arbitrary position on the plate, as shown in Figure 1. The plate can have arbitrary elastic boundary supports along the edges and be mounted on an infinite rigid baffle (e.g. a wall). The plate system is immersed in an infinite light fluid medium (air). The effect of fluid loading on the plate’s vibration is neglected. Figure 1.
Schematic illustration of a stiffened rectangular plate system: (a) A stiffened plate mounted on an infinite rigid baffle; (b) Elastic boundary supports along the edges (for simplicity and clarity, only the supports along the right edge are shown).

sec.title: 2.2. Vibratory motion of the stiffened plate system
2.2.1. Time-domain finite element method (TDFEM)
sec.p: The four-node stiffened plate element (Barik and Mukhopadhyay, 1999) is used in the TDFEM model, in which the displacement field contains the in-plane displacements (u and v), the transverse displacement (w) and the rotational displacements (∂w∂x and ∂w∂y). The mesh size of the element should be determined by considering both the solution accuracy and computational cost. A suggestion proposed by Kim et al. (2003) is a mesh size equal to one quarter of the wavelength of the highest frequency of interest.

The Newmark integration scheme (Robert et al., 2002) is used to integrate the finite element equation (equation (1)) step-by-step in the time domain. The main assumptions of the Newmark method can be expressed as (2){U·(t+Δt)}={U·(t)}+[(1-γ){U··(t)}+γ{U··(t+Δt)}]Δt
(3){U(t+Δt)}={U(t)}+{U·(t)}Δt+[(12-α){U··(t)} +α{U··(t+Δt)}](Δt)2 where Δt is the time step. α and γ are the standard Newmark parameters, which are set to 0.25 and 0.5 (respectively) in our numerical calculations.

sec.title: 2.2.2. Stiffened plate element
sec.p:
The advantages of the stiffened plate element (Barik and Mukhopadhyay, 1999) used in the model are that (1) the stiffeners can be of any shape and their positions inside the element are without any restriction, and (2) the in-plane displacements are taken into account. The stiffness matrix and the mass matrix of this stiffened plate element are given as, (4){Kps}e={Kp}e+{Ks}e, and (5){Mps}e={Mp}e+{Ms}e, where the subscript “e” represents element, {Kp}e and {Ks}e are the stiffness matrices of the plate element and the stiffener element, respectively, and {Mp}e and {Ms}e are the mass matrices of the plate element and the stiffener element, respectively, given as, (6){Mp}e=ρph∫∫{N}T{P}{N}dxdy,
(7){Ms}e=ρs∫{N}T{Ts'}T{Ps}{Ts'}{N}dl,
(8){Kp}e=∫∫{Bp}T{Dp}{Bp}dxdy, and (9){Ks}e=∫({Ts}{Bp})T{Ds}({Ts}{Bp})dl.

The subscripts “p” and “s” represent the plate and the stiffener, respectively. ρ is the density, h is the plate’s thickness, {N} is the shape function vectors for the displacements, l is taken along the stiffener axis, {P} is a diagonal matrix (which is a function of h), {D} is the rigidity matrix, {B} is the strain matrix, and {Ts} and {Ts'} are the transformation matrices relating stiffener global and local axes (which are functions of α. α is the angle between the global axis and the local axis of the stiffener). If the stiffener is curved with its direction changing from point to point, α is not a constant but rather a function of the x coordinate, as shown in Figure 2. Details about these matrices can be found in (Barik and Mukhopadhyay, 1999). Figure 2.
The stiffened plate element. A local (x′, y′) axis is set along the tangent to the stiffener at the integration point making an angle with the global (x, y) axis.

sec.title: 2.2.3. Elastic boundary supports
sec.p: The elastic boundary is idealized by combining elastic springs with ktb, krb, knb, and kmb denoting linear stiffnesses (spring constants) in the transverse direction, in the rotational directions, in the in-plane direction normal to the edge, and in the in-plane direction tangential to the edge, respectively (see Figure 1(b)). The strain energy Π of the elastic boundary in the plate element, as shown in Figure 2, can be given by (10)Πb=∫(12ktbw2+12krb(∂w∂n→b)2+12knb[(u(x→·n→b))2 +(v(y→·n→b))2]+12kmb[(u(x→·n→Γ))2+(v(y→·n→Γ))2])dΓb where the superscript arrow indicates the unit vector, n→b, n→Γ are the unit normal vector and the unit tangent vector of the element boundary contour Γb (see Figure 2). Equation (10) can be written as (11)Πb=12{δ}eT{Kb}e{δ}e, where {δ}e is the nodal displacement vector of the element. {Kb}e can be expressed by, (12){Kb}e=∫(12ktb{Nw}T{Nw}+12krb{∂Nw∂n→b}T{∂Nw∂n→b}+12knb[{Nu}T{Nu}(x→·n→b)2+{Nv}T{Nv}(y→·n→b)2]+12kmb[{Nu}T{Nu}(x→·n→Γ)2+{Nv}T{Nv}(y→·n→Γ)2])dΓb where {Nw}, {Nu} and {Nv} are the shape functions (Barik and Mukhopadhyay, 1999).

Once the mass matrix {Mps}e and the stiffness matrices {Kps}e and {Kb}e are solved by equations (4), (5) and (12), the contributions of the elastic boundary supports and the stiffeners to the global mass matrix {M} and global stiffness matrix {K} of the whole stiffened plate system in equation (1) can be obtained according to the finite element assembly procedure (Robert et al., 2002).

sec.title: 2.3. Sound radiation of the stiffened plate system
sec.p: The time-domain boundary integral equation (Wu, 2000) used to describe the radiated sound field of the plate (Figure 2) is given as (13)C(ξ)p(ξ,t)=∫S∫0tσ*(x,t;ξ,τ)p(x,τ)dτdS -∫S∫0tσ(x,t;ξ,τ)∂p(x,τ)∂n→dτdS, where σ and σ* are the fundamental pressure and fundamental flux, respectively, p is acoustic pressure, the coordinates x and ξ are the source and receiver points respectively, C(ξ) is a constant (Wu, 2000) whose value depends on the location of the point ξ, t represents time, n→ is the unit normal direction on S, and S is the integration area, which includes both the baffle area Sb and the plate area Sp. The flux function ∂p∂n→ can be expressed as ∂p∂n→=-ρ0w··, where ρ0 is the fluid density, and w·· is the normal acceleration of the plate.

If the plate is flat and mounted on an infinite rigid baffle (see Figure 1(a)), similar to the treatment in (Herrin et al., 2006), the half-space fundamental pressure and flux solutions can be employed to avoid modeling of the infinite baffle. Equation (13) can then reduce to the well-known Rayleigh integral equation (14)p(ξ,t)=∫Sp∫0tρ0σH(x,t;ξ,τ)w··(x,τ)dτdSp, where σH=12πrδ(t-rc-τ) is the half-space fundamental pressure solution in time domain. δ is the Dirac delta function, the distance function r=|ξ-x|, and c is the sound propagation speed. It is worth mentioning that equation (14) is valid for p either in the acoustic domain or on the surface Sp.
The numerical implementation method (Herrin et al., 2006) is used to solve equation (14). The plate surface Sp is discretized into a number of boundary elements.

The time-marching scheme is employed to obtain the numerical solution for the unknown p(ξ,t) at each discrete time step, and each step uses the linear time interpolation function. Note that the discretization of the space and time variables is the same as that used in the TDFEM method. Therefore the acceleration results of equation (1) can be directly used in equation (14) to calculate the corresponding radiated sound.

sec.title: 3.1. Comparisons with existing published results
sec.p:
The transient deflection response of a simply supported plate (Figure 3) subjected by a suddenly applied uniform pressure of 0.3 MPa over the entire plate surface has been studied by the proposed method. The plate was 0.203 m long, 0.203 m wide, and 1.37 mm thick with a central eccentric stiffener (6.35 mm × 11.33 mm). The plate and the stiffener were made of the same material with Young’s modulus 68.9 GPa, density 2670 kg/m3, and Poisson’s ratio 0.3. The boundary parameters ktb=∞, knb=∞, kmb=∞ and krb=0 can be used to represent the simply supported boundary condition. In the actual numerical calculation 1 × 1010 was used to represent the infinite number which was found to be large enough to totally constrain the corresponding displacement along the plate edges without bringing numerical difficulties. The element number was 256 (16 × 16) and the time step was 0.05 ms. The time history of deflection at point “B” obtained by the proposed method is presented with those of Jiang and Olson (1991) and Sheikh and Mukhopadhyay (2002) in Figure 4 (the location of point “B” is shown in the figure). A good agreement can be seen among these results. Figure 3.
A simply supported stiffened plate. Point B is at the center of the left half panel.
Figure 4.
Time history of deflection at point “B” of the stiffened plate. Point “B” is shown in Figure 3.

sec.title: 3.2. Parametric studies on a stiffened window
sec.p:
Parametric studies were carried out on an eccentrically stiffened glass window to examine the effects of the stiffeners on the transient vibration and sound radiation (TVSR). The window was 70 cm long, 70 cm wide and 5 mm thick, with the Young’s modulus 65GPs, density 2500 kg/m3, Poisson’s ratio 0.25, and damping factor 0.01.Since the boundary condition of a practical window is usually neither simply supported nor clamped but the one between them (Utley and Fletcher, 1973; Quirt, 1982), the boundary parameters ktb, knb, kmb and k¯rb were set to 1 × 1010, 1 × 1010, 1 × 1010 and 10, respectively. Here, k¯rb is the dimensionless forms of krb (k¯rb=krbLx/D, D is the flexural rigidity of the plate), which are the same as those used in (Chiello et al., 2003; Ou and Mak, 2011a,b). In real applications, one can use the boundary condition identification (BCI) method (Ou and Mak, 2011a) to determine the approximate boundary condition of a practical window.Curve stiffeners were used in this parametric study; these are seldom reported in the available literature but could have potential applications to the window design (e.g. the design from an aesthetic point of view). As shown in Figure 5, four identical quarter-circular shape eccentric stiffeners with a radius of rs were located at each corner of the window. Considering the window’s transparency, the stiffeners were made of the same material as the window. The cross-section dimensions of the stiffener cross section are 5 mm in width and 20 mm in thickness. It can be seen from the figure that the location of the stiffeners was now only dependent on the radius rs. The effects of different locations of the stiffeners on the TVSR were examined by changing the value of rs. Figure 5.
Schematic diagram of the stiffened window.

The stiffened window was impacted at normal incidence by a transient sound pulse (a half-sine wave), as shown in Figure 6. Figure 7 shows the resulting acceleration response at point “A” while Figure 8 shows the resulting radiated sound pressure at point “P”. Point “A” is the midpoint of the plate and point “P” is on the axis of symmetry a distance of 0.1 m away from the plate. For comparison, the predictions of the same window without stiffeners are also included in the figures. To make more comprehensive comparisons between these responses, a fast Fourier transform (FFT) was used to convert the responses into frequency spectrum data, as shown in Figures 7(b) and 8(b). The element number and time interval Δt used in the numerical calculation were 256 (16 × 16) and 0.5 ms, respectively. Figure 6.
A transient sound pulse (a half-sine wave): (a) Pressure time history; (b) Pressure frequency spectrum (1 Hz ∼ 1 kHz).
Figure 7.
Acceleration response at point “A”: (a) Acceleration time history; (b) Acceleration frequency spectrum (1 Hz ∼ 1 kHz). Point “A” is the midpoint of the plate.
Figure 8.
Radiated sound pressure at point “P”: (a) Pressure time history; (b) Pressure frequency spectrum (1 Hz ∼ 1 kHz). Point “P” is on the axis of symmetry a distance of 0.1 m away from the plate.

It can be seen clearly from Figures 7 and 8 that the TVSR responses of the stiffened window are different from those of the unstiffened window. Also, different stiffener locations (or rs) lead to different TVSR responses. One main effect of the stiffeners (and their locations) is that they can influence the resonant frequencies of the structure (window). Stiffening the window at proper locations can shift the resonant frequencies to higher values, and the TVSR responses of the window can therefore be reduced when impacted by the transient loads having higher energy in low-frequency range. This type of loads (noise) commonly exists in the daily life and is of particular concern because of its efficient propagation and reduced efficacy of many building structures in attenuating low-frequency noise compared with other noise (Berglund et al., 1996).

The maximum values of the acceleration level Amax=max[20lg(|w··(t)|w··ref)] and radiated sound pressure level SPLmax=max[20lg(|p(t)|pref)] can be easily obtained from the TVSR responses and are shown in Figure 9 as a function of rs, where w··(t) is the nodal accelerations of the whole plate and p(t) is the sound pressure at point “P”. It can bee seen from the figure that the stiffener location (or rs) has a notable effect on Amax and SPLmax of the window. In this case, there exists an optimum value (around rs=45 cm) at which Amax and SPLmax are minimized. Reductions of about 10 dB and 8 dB can be obtained in Amax and SPLmax, respectively, in comparison with those of the unstiffened window. Figure 9.
The maximum values of the acceleration level and radiated sound pressure level as a function of rs (0 < rs < 0.7 m, the step of rs was 0.05 m): (a) Maximum acceleration level; (b) Maximum radiated sound pressure level.

In a word, the simulations in this parametric study show that stiffeners have a significant effect on the TVSR of a window. The maximum values of the acceleration and radiated sound pressure can be effectively reduced by stiffening the window at proper positions.

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: A time-domain prediction method was developed to examine the TVSR of a stiffened rectangular plate based on the TDFEM and TDBEM. In the model, the plate can have arbitrary elastic boundary conditions, and the stiffeners with any shape can be located at arbitrary positions inside the plate. The in-plane deformation of the plate is taken into account. Comparing the predicted transient vibration response using the present approach with earlier published results showed a good agreement.

Parametric studies were carried out on a glass window stiffened by curve-shape stiffeners. The results showed that the stiffeners had a significant effect on the window’s TVSR. Stiffening the window at proper positions could be a potential way to reduce the window’s maximum acceleration and maximum sound pressure due to transient excitations. The results also demonstrated the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed model as a design tool. Although the effects of the stiffeners were the focus of the parametric studies, the current method can also be applied to examine the effects of arbitrary elastic boundary conditions on the TVSR of a stiffened window.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU Project account) (grant number G-YJ78).
